ratings.question_text: What percentage of the reading and other assignments did you complete?

narratives.question_text: How well was the course organized?
comments: I think my main struggle throughout the class was trying to piece together the order of the syllabus. Was there a progression? Why not start with Le Bon? To me there seems to have been overlap between some of the material, so after a while it felt like we were treading repeat ground, particularly toward the end when we had gathered that crowd theorists were saying the same things about crowd...over and over again (i.e., crowds are easily manipulated, etc.).

narratives.question_text: How effective was the balance between instruction and discussion?
How well did the assigned papers, reports or other projects reflect the aims of the course?
comments: While I appreciate class presentations and think they are excellent tools for getting everyone to participate and become responsible for the material, I wonder whether a method aimed at capitalist market trade design presentations (the pecha kucha) is the right method for a presentation about different subject matters around mass performances. Might there not be a more organic solution? Impose a time limit, yes, by all means, because brevity is of the essence; however, don't impose a slide limit/time limit for each slide. It gets to be too static for the development of an argument, which doesn't always take the shape of a product presentation.

narratives.question_text: How did the amount of assigned reading work with weekly discussion?
comments: The balance between reading and viewing was great. Manageable for YSD and chunky enough for analysis in class.
Keep pushing the group viewings. Maybe we need to assign a day of the week and a place. LIke a weekday and a YSD classroom space. Make it more official. (Attendance list?)

narratives.question_text: The course filled a significant gap in your knowledge of the field.
comments: I didn't know anything about crowd theories before taking this class, so that really fulfilled a large gap in literature, and I definitely learned more about authoritarian governments and how theater/performance plays a role in the dispersal of government ideology. Now I'm seeing fascism at every turn. My question, though, has to do with mass performance itself. I'm still a bit confused as to what classifies as a mass performance. For example, while hell houses are definitely part of the crowd theory section of the course, how do they qualify as a mass performance? They seem to be very different from the Spartakiads and other mass gymnastics-like events.

narratives.question_text: Regardless of whether or not the course is required, would you recommend it to other students in and outside the department?
comments: For anyone interested in crowd theory and 19th/20th-cent political history!

narratives.question_text: The course goals were clearly presented.
comments: As mentioned above, still having a hard time putting together the crowd theory with the mass performance theory. At times the class felt more like crowd theory than it did mass performance. How are they brought together? Maybe it's my fault for not parsing it out, but perhaps a more overt bringing together of the two and having a semester-long constant defining of terms might help.

narratives.question_text: The instructor has a strong grasp of the course subject matter.
The instructor presented the subject matter effectively.
comments: Still room for improvement, as seen above in comments.

narratives.question_text: The instructor was willing to consider diverse points of view.
The instructor was willing to answer pertinent questions.
The grading criteria was clearly explained.
The instructor was available for consultation, discussion and advice.
I would recommend this instructor to other students.
comments: Yes, Kimberly has the spark of youth and is super-game to get you to think and join the academic conversation even outside this institution. That's a plus! Love hearing about conference opportunities, lectures at Yale and outside, etc.

narratives.question_text: How many of the 14 class meetings did you attend?  Comments:
Please offer additional comments you have on such topics as: what worked best about the course, what improvements you would suggest, etc.
comments: Main takeaway: more diversity in types of crowd theory, a more explicit definition of mass performance, and maybe a more established chronology of material.
